2.text:
Question 2

(a)

3.text:
3 (a) Any two odd primes added correctly  
• 1 mark (AO2.1a)  
  e.g. 3 + 5 = 8  

(b) An odd integer squared with correct result  
• 1 mark (AO2.1a)  
  e.g. 5² = 25

4.text:
4

M1 for 1/4 + 1/2 = 3/4 (soi)  
M1 for 1/4 (of the rent) = 450  
M1 for 450 × 4 (oe using percentages or decimals)

7 (a)

(b)

8.text:
8 (a)  
Answer: 8  
Marks: 3 (2 AO1.3a, 1 AO3.1b)  

• M1 for dividing by 3 or 13  
• M1 for dividing by the remaining factor  
• M1 for multiplying 3 by 13  
• M1 for dividing by 39 or listing multiples of 39  

(b)  
Answer: Any three valid answers (e.g. 2, 7, 23)  
Marks: 3 (1 AO1.1, 2 AO3.1a)  

• B1 for each  
• If 0 scored, instead award SC1 for at least 3 primes and 3 squares seen

9.text:
9 (a)  
Answer: 2  
Marks: 2 (1 AO1.1, 1 AO2.1a)  
• B1 for 2 correct.  

Prism         | Number of faces | Number of edges | Number of vertices  
Triangular     (3 sides)  | 5               | 9               | 6  
Rectangular  (4 sides)   | 6               | 12              | 8  
Pentagonal    (5 sides)  | 7               | 15              | 10  
Hexagonal     (6 sides)  | 8               | 18              | 12  

(b)  
Answer: 300 (edges), 200 (vertices)  
Marks: 2 (2 AO2.1a)  
• 1 mark for 300 (edges).  
• 1 mark for 200 (vertices).  

(c)  
Answer: F = N + 2 (or equivalent)  
Marks: 2 (1 AO2.3a, 1 AO2.3b)  
• B1 for N + 2 (without a subject).  
• Condone for B1 a correct word formula.

10.text:
10 (a) (i)  
Answer: Positive correlation  
Marks: 1 (1 AO1.1)  
Guidance:  
• Condone “positive” or correct description (e.g. “As the temperature increases, more ice creams are sold”).

(a) (ii)  
Answer: Correct reason, e.g. “He sold far more ice creams than you would expect him to for a 20°C day.”  
Marks: 1 (1 AO2.3a)

(b) (i)  
Answer: 75–95  
Marks: 1 (1 AO1.3a)

(b) (ii)  
Answer: 140–170  
Marks: 1 (1 AO1.3a)

(b) (iii)  
Answer: The (b)(i) prediction is more reliable, as it is within the range of the given data.  
Marks: 2 (1 AO2.1b, 1 AO2.4a)  
Guidance:  
• B1 for (b)(i) prediction identified with partial reason.

(c)  
Answer: No, because there may be other factors involved.  
Marks: 2 (1 AO2.5a, 1 AO3.4b)  
Guidance:  
• B1 for “No”, with partial reason.

11.text:
11 (a)  
Answer: 45 000  
Marks: 2 (2 AO1.3a)  
  
• M1 for 50 000 × 0.9 soi, or 50 000 − 5000  

11 (b)  
Answer: Total value of goods sold in May was £32 805, which is less than £35 000  
Marks: 3 (3 AO2.2)  
  
• M2 for 50 000 (or 45 000) × 0.9 used three times (or two times) soi or decreasing by 10% three times  
  (implied by 36 450 and 32 805)  
  OR  
• M1 for 45 000 × 0.9 or 45 000 − 4500  
  (implied by 40 500)  

11 (c)  
Answer: 8[%] with correct working  
Marks: 5 (3 AO1.3b, 2 AO3.1d)  
  
• B4 for answer 108[%] or 1.08 or [0].08 with correct working  
  OR  
• M3 for 1.2 × [0].9 oe  
   or for (100 000 × 1.2 × [0].9 − 100 000) / 100 000  
  OR  
• M2 for 1.2 and [0].9  
  OR  
• M1 for 1.2 or [0].9  

If 0 or 1 scored, instead award SC2 for answer 8[%] with no working or insufficient working.  
If 0 scored, instead award SC1 for 108[%] or 1.08 or [0].08 with no working or insufficient working.  

“Correct working” requires evidence of at least M3 or an alternative convincing approach.  

Throughout, percentage calculations may be performed in stages (e.g. 120% by adding 20%).  
Examples:  
• 100 000 × 1.2 × [0].9 or 120 000 × [0].9  
• 100 000 × 1.2 (implied by 120 000)

12.text:
12 (a)  
Answer: 6 (2 marks)  
∙ 2 AO1.3a  
   – M1 for 3x = 18  

12 (b)  
Answer: –3, –5 (3 marks)  
∙ 3 AO1.3a  
   – M2 for (x + 3)(x + 5) seen or implied in table  
     or  
     M1 for (x ± 3)(x ± 5) seen, or for a pair of factors giving two correct terms seen or implied in table  
   – B1 for correct solutions, following through their quadratic factors

15.text:
15 (a)  
Answer: 800  
Marks: 2 (1 AO1.3b, 1 AO3.1c)  

Part marks and guidance:  
• M1 for unitary work, e.g. 1 person does 200 letters in 2 hours  

(b)  
Answer: 30 minutes oe  
Marks: 4 (2 AO2.1a, 2 AO3.1d)  

Part marks and guidance:  
• M1 for 1 person does 100 letters in 1 hour  
• M1 for 5 people do 1000 letters in 2 hours  
• M1 for 4 people do 1000 letters in 2.5 hours  
• FT from their rate in (a) throughout  

(c)  
Answer:  
– Correct comment on the reasonableness of her assumption  
   (e.g. “She has assumed that ‘all day’ means ‘for 24 hours’,  
   but it is not reasonable for them to work without a break.”)  

– Correct comment on the effect it will have on the answer  
   (e.g. “They can’t work at that rate for that long,  
   so her answer is an over-estimate.”)  

Marks: 2 (1 AO3.4a, 1 AO3.5)  
Part marks and guidance:  
• B1 for each

16.text:

18.text:
18 (a)  
Answer:  
• The first error is in step 2: −3x − 2x = −5x, not −x as given  

Marks: 2  
(2 AO2.5a)  

Part marks and guidance:  
• B1 for identifying step 2  
• B1 for explaining the error  

(b)  
Answer:  
[x² + 4x + x + 4 = x² − 3x − 2x + 6]  
x² + 5x + 4 = x² − 5x + 6  
5x + 4 = −5x + 6  
10x + 4 = 6  
10x = 2  
x = 1/5  

Marks: 2  
(2 AO1.3a)  

Part marks and guidance:  
• M1 for an attempt to correct the solution in line with their answer to (a)

19.text:
19  
Answer: 2a + 1  
Marks: 4  
(1 AO1.3b, 2 AO3.1b, 1 AO3.2)

• M1 for a + 2 + 3a + 3 + 4a – 1  
• M1 for collecting terms  
• M1 for dividing their “8a + 4” by 4
